He was later able to connect to a raw kyber crystal, which turned green and allowed him to speak with Yoda, but the unsteadiness of the Force at that time left him trapped in his vision until Yoda helped him realize that just like the sun did not disappear during the night, the Force would also always be there. Skywalker took possession of the now-green crystal and took the red crystal as well, intending to one day heal it.[185]

Years later, during his rescue of Grogu, Skywalker used the Force to destroy Dark Troopers by throwing them off ledges, pushing them away, smashing crates into them/flinging debris at them, and crushing them with the Force.[18]

Skywalker was skilled at doing mind tricks,[12] as well as performing Force-enhanced jumps.[69][11][12] He also demonstrated the ability to have visions several times.[48][11] Skywalker could disconnect himself from the Force, and he was able to renew his connection within a short amount of time.[216][247] Luke Skywalker understood the dark side powers mind probe, Force-bond, and Force lightning well enough to write about them. On at least one occasion, he healed the bled kyber crystal from a Sith lightsaber.[7] He also studied Force healing and many esoteric Force powers.[4][7] Snoke considered Skywalker to be very powerful and formidable and believed he would have taken over the galaxy quickly with Skywalker as his apprentice.[244]

When using the force to restrain an archeologist possessed by a Sith spirit on Yoturba, Luke had to concentrate very carefully to restrain his power so that he did not accidentally kill the man. Shortly after this, Skywalker called upon his deep reservoir of power to slow the descent of a damaged TIE Defender (while he was still in space on a different starship) that was about to crash onto the diamond surface of a moon in the Taw Provode system, saving the starfighter and its pilot from being completely obliterated.[7] When facing the Knights of Ren, Skywalker effortlessly Force-pushed the Knights of Ren and telekinetically disarmed and destroyed their weapons.[233]

After the fall of Ben Solo and the destruction of his Jedi Temple, Skywalker spent years himself how to close himself off from the Force, an ability he considered much more difficult than reaching out to it in the first place.[246] Shortly after reopening himself to the Force, Luke detected Rey and Ren's bond and in his anger, he Force pushed Rey's hut into pieces around the two and broke the connection. When defending himself against Rey, Luke pried an antenna from the roof of a hut and summoned it to himself in seconds, then managed to keep himself suspended off the ground after being knocked down by Rey. Whereas Ren noted that the effort of attempting Force projection would kill Rey, Skywalker was able to use the complete version of this ability; he gave all of himself into the Force, which allowed him to interact with others[4] by sending a life-like image of himself across the galaxy to distract Kylo Ren and the First Order. The projection was so powerful that C-3PO acknowledged his presence, and Ren was tricked into believing it was the real him. Skywalker maintained it for a prolonged period of time, although the strain ultimately proved to be fatal and killed the Jedi Master.[19]

Skywalker was one of the few Jedi who was able to truly become one with the Force and preserve his consciousness as a Force spirit. As a Force spirit, Skywalker was able to physically interact with the living world, which he demonstrated when he caught the Skywalker lightsaber after Rey threw it, and when he lifted his X-wing from the oceans of Ahch-To and repaired it so that she could travel to Exegol.[17]

Other abilities

"Luke is the best bush pilot in the Outer Rim Territories."
―Biggs Darklighter boasts about Luke's piloting skills to Garven Dreis[1]

Skywalker was acknowledged to be an expert pilot, being the person who was responsible for destroying the first Death Star and managing to evade Darth Vader himself (albeit with help from Han Solo).[1] He also managed to destroy an Interdictor vessel on his own while piloting the Desert Jewel, although he acknowledged that R2-D2 saved him when the astromech droid made the ship jump into hyperspace in the nick of time.[54] He was also able to pilot a Imperial Lambda-class T-4a shuttle with relative ease, outmaneuvering an RZ-1 A-wing interceptor that was trying to get a lock on him.[198] In fact, Skywalker had a talent for tinkering and a passion for speed.[245] With no previous experience, Skywalker was able to pilot a podracer with incredible skill, a feat that an announcer and Vader acknowledged was impressive.[58] He was considered to be one of the Alliance's best pilots[123] and gained recognition and fame amongst them for his skills because he made the shot that destroyed the Death Star.[156] He was able to pilot a shuttle into Cloud City and avoid the shots from its turret defenses though he worried he would get them killed.[143] He briefly bested Vader in a dogfight over Jekara, tricking him into crashing.[162] His piloting and targeting skills were limited by his fear occasionally, and on one instance he missed a shot because he had a vision of Vader defeating Solo during the Battle of Yavin.[156]

He was even able to use a jetpack[176] and was skilled with a speeder, once using one to take down an Imperial transport.[128] However, he once attempted to drive a boat and ended up capsizing it.[147] He also could perform environmental surveys, largely to due farming skills he gained from his time on Tatooine.[102]

He was a native speaker of Galactic Basic Standard,[1] and although Skywalker could not understand Shyriiwook, he had quickly learned how to read Chewbacca's moods by his tone and expression before the Battle of Yavin.[6] After decades of missions with R2, Skywalker was reasonably fluent in droidspeak.[247]

Skywalker was adept in unarmed combat. He demonstrated his skill early on Cymoon 1 where he defeated a few stormtroopers by kicking and slamming them to the ground.[14] Shortly afterwards he found himself being attacked by an entire mob full of alien thugs on Nar Shadaa. Skywalker defeated numerous of the attackers unarmed before igniting his lightsaber and startling the rest.[68] He found himself in another similar situation on Horox III, where he defeated an entire cantina of alien thugs with the help of Aphra and her Wookiee bounty hunter.[89] Skywalker knocked out the Commander Kanchar, a hulking cybernetic enhanced man with a single punch after outsmarting him.[101] He was able to take down a muscled individual who was much larger than him using only a broom.[123] However, Ellian Zahra was able to knock him down in an encounter where she was holding back, though he easily dodged her sword attack.[150]

He was also capable with a blaster,[1] and could also escape ropes tied around his hands quickly, a skill Doctor Aphra theorized he learned from Han Solo.[179] It took him time to get used to fighting with a blaster and hand-to-hand with his prosthetic hand, however.[142] He was capable with a grappling hook and could use it to both swing[1] and pull items down.[129] He also knew how to swim.[107]

In his later years, Skywalker displayed such skill that he was able to easily punch aside a Knight of Ren[233] and disarm Rey of her quarterstaff before she could react.[19]

Equipment

Lightsabers

Main article: Skywalker lightsaber
Main article: Luke Skywalker's yellow lightsaber
Main article: Luke Skywalker's green lightsaber
Luke's lightsaber, used by his father before him.
Skywalker built a new lightsaber after losing his father's weapon.

Luke Skywalker wielded at least three lightsabers during the Galactic Civil War. The first was his father's former weapon, that was retrieved and given to him by Obi-Wan Kenobi.[1] He wielded this weapon for three years before losing it, and the hand holding it, in a duel against Darth Vader on the cloud city on Bespin.[11]

The second one he obtained shortly after his visit to a Jedi outpost on Tempes. This saber was a lightsaber pike with only the still functional half of the lightsaber. Luke eventually fixed the damaged end and continued using this one to defend himself against foes like Commander Ellian Zahra.[150] While in No-Space, this lightsaber was crushed and mangled by a killdroid. R2-D2 attempted to fix it, and while it still ignited, it often dangerously sputtered and crackled with energy.[177] Dr. Cuata eventually repaired it.[185]

Eventually, Skywalker built himself a new weapon, with a green blade, that he used to rescue his friends from Jabba the Hutt and during his final duel with Darth Vader.[12]

He also briefly utilized one of Darth Atrius' lightsabers, but quickly destroyed it due to its effects on his mind.[58]

Blasters

Skywalker would carry several blasters. During his youth on Tatooine, he had a 6-2Aug2 hunting rifle when he went to search for R2 but it was destroyed when he was subsequently ambushed in the Jundland Wastes by the Tusken Raider A'Koba. While rescuing Leia from the Death Star, Luke used an E-11 medium blaster rifle. During the Award ceremony that occurred shortly after the Battle of Yavin, Skywalker had a Defender sporting blaster pistol.[1]He later owned a heavy blaster pistol similar to a DL-44.[11]

Behind the scenes

Portrayal in the Skywalker Saga

Original trilogy

For most of his appearances in Star Wars saga, Luke Skywalker was portrayed by actor Mark Hamill.[1] For his appearance in Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith, Skywalker was portrayed as a infant by Aidan Barton.[13]

Luke Skywalker's character went through subsequent changes. In George Lucas' original script, Skywalker was meant to be called Luke Starkiller,[268] at one point the character was a girl,[269] and Lucas even considered the main character to be a little person.[270] Luke Skywalker's first name is identical with George Lucas' high school nickname.[271] That Skywalker is urged by his uncle Owen Lars—who serves as the boy's father figure—to give up on his dreams and instead work in the family business, in his case moisture farming, can also be connected to Lucas' life, where his father George Lucas Sr. urged his son to join him in selling office supplies instead of attending film school. Furthermore, Skywalker also suffers great injuries throughout the saga,[272] such as being attacked by a wampa and losing his hand in Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back alone,[11] much as Lucas himself did in a 1962 car crash that almost killed the future director. The injuries suffered by Luke's father Anakin Skywalker can also be connected to Lucas' car crash. Lucas has indeed stated he put parts of himself into the characters of Anakin and Luke, reflecting that over his life he had wanted to be a Han Solo-like person, yet he instead found himself to be more of a Skywalker.[272]

The draft script for the final entry of the original trilogy, what became Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi, had Luke fight the Emperor aboard Death Star II with the assistance of the Force spirits of both his masters, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda. Skywalker would have been defended by both when Palpatine unleashed his Force lightning. Kenobi, Yoda, and Anakin Skywalker also returned to having physical forms in the script, allowing Luke to hug his resurrected father.[273] Skywalker's black costume in Return of the Jedi was intentionally designed to invoke Vader's also dark outfit.[274]

Sequel trilogy

"If you look at any classic hero's myth that is actually worth its salt, at the beginning of the hero's journey, like with King Arthur, he pulls the sword from the stone and he's ascendant â€” he has setbacks but he unites all the kingdoms. But then if you keep reading, when it deals with the hero's life as they get into middle-age and beyond, it always starts to get into darker places. And there's a reason for that: It's because myths are not made to sell action figures; myths are made to reflect the most difficult transitions we go through in life."
―Rian Johnson on Luke's characterization in The Last Jedi[275]

George Lucas's sequel trilogy outline involved a Luke who had fallen into a dark state of mind, living in self-imposed exile in the first Jedi Temple. (He is described in 2013 concept art as "a Colonel Kurtz type.")[276] However, Lucas did not give a reason for Luke's change of attitude.[277] Michael Arndt's initial script for The Force Awakens had Luke first appear halfway through the film, but Arndt came to feel that Luke's direct involvement would upstage Rey and the audience would cease caring about her. Ultimately, he, J.J. Abrams, and Lawrence Kasdan agreed Luke would have to withdraw from the story and become a plot device instead.[278] Hamill still attended the cast's script reading, thereby concealing Luke's role, and was assigned to read the stage directions. "It was a way of having [him] be part of every scene, every moment, not just spiritually or thematically or narratively, but actually," Abrams said. "Having his voice in it made the read through a better experience for everyone."[279]

Hamill was initially concerned by how Luke was written in The Last Jedi. "I got into trouble because… I was quoted as saying to Rian [Johnson] that I fundamentally disagree with everything you decided about Luke, and it was inartfully [sic] phrased. What I was, was surprised at how he saw Luke. And it took me a while to get around to his way of thinking, but once I was there it was a thrilling experience. I hope it will be for the audience too."[280] Johnson explained: "Honestly, that came out of what I felt was a necessity, because it came from where he was at the end of Episode VII, The Force Awakens. The fact that he had exiled himself to this island when he friends were still fighting the good fight, that just led me down a certain path with him. I couldn't really see any other alternative.";[281] "Knowing that Luke is a hero, knowing Luke from growing up, I know he must think he's doing the right thing by taking himself out of the equation. And because he's the last Jedi, by taking the Jedi out of the equation, by saying, 'I'm taking the Jedi out of this fight,' he must think that's the best thing for the galaxy."[282] Hamill agreed that an old, comfortable Luke would have been too reminiscent of Obi-Wan, but his issue was that "'Jedis [sic] don't give up.'" Johnson added the back-and-forth to get Luke's character to make sense helped "made me really dig in and justify the choices I had made to bring Luke to where he was at. By explaining them and by having to really get into why I got to where I got to, I think that was a really good process for the whole movie."[283] To get into character, Hamill thought of the real life hopes and disappointments of his generation.[284]

Johnson deemed it best to conclude Luke's Last Jedi arc with him dying partly because, "honestly, thinking about the number of characters we have on our plate going into the next movie [...] it just vaguely seemed good to me that putting Luke in another realm could open possibilities for his possible involvement in the next one. As opposed to him just being another character that had to be juggled into the plot, if that makes sense." He was unconcerned that the audience might feel unable to cope with Luke's death so soon after Han's murder in The Force Awakens, as Luke's passing was victorious and peaceful, not a violent defeat.[285] Hamill was particularly not keen on Luke dying, feeling he had to return a triumphant hero, but Johnson argued that "if Skywalker just came back like he did in the original trilogy, an optimistic fighter, he's just an older version of Rey. And Johnson needed someone to bounce up against Rey."[286] Hamill said his primary lesson from the experience was how, "At times, I'd say to Rian, 'We gotta think of what the audience wants,' "And he would say, 'No, we've gotta think of what we want.'"[287]

Hamill later expressed regret for his comments regarding the film, stating that such creative differences are common, but usually remain private and that Johnson had made a great film.[288] He later disclosed he had similarly disputed the way the character was written in Return of the Jedi, revealing "I read [the script for] Jedi and thought, 'Wait a sec! I thought I was heading toward the struggle of heading to the Dark Side. I'm in black. I have a glove. I see a trend here.'"[289]

The Rise of Skywalker reveals Luke and Leia knew about Rey's ancestry, despite the revelation not having been conceived during production of the previous two films. Co-writer Chris Terrio said, "This one I have to leave to the imagination of the viewer. But, I don't think it would be wrong to assume that Luke's Force Ghost would seek out his Force-sensitive, Jedi-trained sister."[290]

Portrayal on Disney+

The Mandalorian and The Book of Boba Fett

In Star Wars: The Mandalorian's "Chapter 16: The Rescue," Max Lloyd Jones physically portrayed the character, with Matt Rugetti serving as a stunt double.[18] Both Hamill and Jones were filmed—Jones with all of the cast, and Hamill when most of the cast and crew were filming outside of the studio. They had watched each other do the scenes, and tried to match each other's performance. Lola's digital de-aging was used to make the character look like young Luke Skywalker, and the voice was completely synthesised using an application called Respeecher. To prevent this appearance from leaking, the scripts had Plo Koon written instead of Luke Skywalker, and a concept art of Plo Koon destroying dark troopers was created.[291]

In Star Wars: The Book of Boba Fett, Graham Hamilton was the performance artist for the character, with Scott Lang serving as a stunt double. The voice was artificially created with Respeecher.[292] Rosario Dawson, who played Ahsoka Tano in The Book of Boba Fett,[229] didn't learn that her character would interact with Luke Skywalker until the day of filming. She was very excited that she got to work with Mark Hamill.[293]

Portrayal in Obi-Wan Kenobi

"And [Obi-Wan Kenobi] sees a guy in a dark robe with a red lightsaber, and he's like, 'Anakin, Anakin, Anakin!' And as… the guy in the robe comes up, he lifts his lightsaber, you see, it's Luke. Mark Hamill, 19. And so, Luke attacks him. Obi-Wan and Luke had this lightsaber battle in mine, which was mirroring, of course, Empire Strikes Back… so it was that kind of a thing that ends with, you know, Luke, just almost killing Obi-Wan, and Obi-Wan is snapping out of the, you know, the vision, basically, but it's a vision of the future if Obi-Wan keeps training Luke and putting all his guilt on this kid, Luke's gonna turn to the Dark Side."
―Stuart Beattie describing the script for his Obi-Wan Kenobi feature film[294]

In Stuart Beattie's script for an Obi-Wan Kenobi feature film, when Kenobi left Tatooine, he left clone trooper Cody in charge of Luke Skywalker, which was meant to be a side plot that the film would cut away to. Cody was planned as a way to show how disconnected Kenobi was from the Force due to forcing his will upon young Skywalker in a manner similar to when Superman lost his powers in the 1980 film Superman II. Kenobi would fall in with refugees that are fleeing from the Empire. Tao, the lead refugee woman, took Kenobi to a sacred shrine and instructed the Jedi Master to let their goddess speak to him. Kenobi was then on Mustafar and was attacked by Luke Skywalker played by a de-aged Mark Hamill. Skywalker almost killed Kenobi, but he snapped out the vision and realized that putting his guilt on Skywalker would turn him to the dark side. Beattie was excited to be part of the first Star Wars project to bring back Skywalker.[294]

Skywalker was portrayed by Grant Feely as a young kid in Part I,[26] Part V,[29] and Part VI of the Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi limited television series.[30] In April, 2021,[295] Feely's agent sent him the audition for a role.[296] He then filmed an audition for "Boy - Untitled Disney+ Series," not knowing the role was for Obi-Wan Kenobi,[295] and he did not think anything of it.[296] A week later, he had an hour-long Zoom callback with Carmen Cuba, the casting director for the series. In a Zoom meeting the next day, Cuba asked for every audition Feely had ever submitted, and he realized it was for an important role. In early June, he had a director's callback with director Deborah Chow.[295] When he was in Hawaii[296] during the end of June,[295] he was asked if he could come to Los Angeles. He was not able to go, so they flew him to LA[296] to do an in-person audition with Chow. In early July, Chow called Feely to offer him the role of Luke Skywalker.[295] For about nine months, Feely kept his role a secret and only told his close family.[297]

Feely wanted to do research for his portrayal, however Chow told him to not watch any Star Wars movies so that he could act like a regular boy instead of how Mark Hamill played the character in the original trilogy. Chow explained that Skywalker does not learn about the Force until he's around twenty years old.[296] He was not told anything about Skywalker or any other characters in the series.[297] When the rock scene[295] of Skywalker being chased by the Inquisitor Reva[30] was being filmed, Feely was in a harness running along the top of the set.[295]

Other appearances

In Episode IV: A New Hope Read-Along Storybook and CD, Skywalker was voiced by Joshua Fardon.[298] When he wrote the 2020 relaunch of the mainline Star Wars comic, which was set between The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi, author Charles Soule knew that Skywalker's emotional journey between the events of both films was key factor in bridging their gap. In sculpting Skywalker's path between those movies, he found that one story arc,[299] the two issue The Sith and the Skywalker storyline,[300][301] was quite important to Skywalker's journey. Due to its importance, he was happy to see fans enjoy it.[299]

Trials on Tatooine

"Good luck with whatever Luke has you doing down here."
―Han Solo to Skywalker's student about Luke[302]

In the cinematic virtual-reality game, Star Wars: Trials on Tatooine, after Skywalker had many journeys to the distant corners of the galaxy, uncovering secrets about the legacy of the Jedi, he felt ready to create a new Jedi Order. He took on a padawan learner, who was hoping to join the Jedi Order, and sent the Padawan on a mission to Tatooine to await a delivery from Han Solo. The Millennium Falcon landed, and R2-D2 handed the Padawan a lightsaber. However, remnants of the Galactic Empire began an operation to attack the Padawan.[302]

Role in LEGO Star Wars

LEGO animated series

"Rowan, May the Force be With You."
―Luke Skywalker to Rowan Freemaker after their first meeting[303]

Even though Skywalker's appearances in various LEGO Star Wars content are not a part of the official Star Wars canon, they are set in a unique, continuous universe.[304] In the LEGO Star Wars television series LEGO Star Wars: The Freemaker Adventures, Skywalker was often alluded to, but the man himself only made three physical appearances: the episodes "Crossing Paths,"[303] "Trouble on Tibalt,"[305] and "Return of the Return of the Jedi,"[306] where he was voiced by Eric Bauza.[303]

Skywalker also made appearance[307] in the five-episode limited series LEGO Star Wars: Droid Tales, a series that re-told the story of the live-action Star Wars films, from Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace through Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi, albeit in a rather silly and exaggerated fashion, as well as a similarly-portrayed adaptation of the Star Wars Rebels episode "Droids in Distress."[308] Skywalker was once again voiced by Eric Bauza in the series.[307]

LEGO video games

For the LEGO Star Wars: The Force Awakens video game, Mark Hamill reprised his role as Skywalker, albeit through archive footage and not newly-recorded dialogue.[309] In LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga, he was voiced by David Menkin, who was overjoyed to play the iconic character.[310] In this game, Skywalker is presented as having tried to deal with the rising darkness of Ben Solo during the time of the Jedi academy in a calm and non-threatening way, only drawing his lightsaber to block an attack from the younger man.[311]

LEGO Star Wars Holiday Specials

Skywalker would make an appearance in The LEGO Star Wars Holiday Special, once again voiced by Eric Bauza.[312] Skywalker then would make an appearance in LEGO Star Wars Terrifying Tales in the segments, "The Lost Boy" and "The Wookiee Paw". He was once again voiced by Eric Bauza.[313]

  26. â†‘ 26.0 26.1 26.2 26.3 26.4 Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi — "Part I"
  27. â†‘ Star Wars: Dawn of Rebellion: The Visual Guide
  28. â†‘ Star Wars: Timelines dates Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi to 9 BBY.
  29. â†‘ 29.0 29.1 29.2 Star Wars: Obi-Wan Kenobi — "Part V"

  31. â†‘ 31.0 31.1 31.2 31.3 Star Wars (2015) 7
  32. â†‘ 32.0 32.1 Star Wars (2015) 20
  33. â†‘ Star Wars (2015) 15
  34. â†‘ 34.0 34.1 34.2 Star Wars LINE Webtoon
  35. â†‘ Star Wars Adventures Ashcan
  36. â†‘ 36.0 36.1 36.2 Star Wars: The Complete Visual Dictionary, New Edition
  37. â†‘ According to Star Wars: Absolutely Everything You Need to Know, Updated and Expanded, Maul final confrontation with Obi-Wan Kenobi in "Twin Suns" happened thirty years after Kenobi first saw him on Tatooine. Since Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates that event to 32 BBY, Kenobi and Maul's final confrontation happened in 2 BBY.

  56. â†‘ 56.0 56.1 56.2 "Swoop Racers" — Star Wars Adventures (2017) 21
  57. â†‘ According to Star Wars Adventures #21 on IDW Publishing's official website (backup link), "Swoop Racers", in which the event appears, takes place just after Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope, which Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates to 0 ABY. Therefore "Swoop Racers" must take place in the same year as well.

  206. â†‘ 206.0 206.1 206.2 Shattered Empire 4
  207. â†‘ Star Wars: Galactic Atlas says that Shara Bey and Kes Dameron moved to Yavin 4 in 5 ABY. They moved shortly after the mission to Vetine, placing this event in 5 ABY.

  216. â†‘ 216.00 216.01 216.02 216.03 216.04 216.05 216.06 216.07 216.08 216.09 216.10 216.11 216.12 216.13 Star Wars: The Secrets of the Jedi
  217. â†‘ Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary states that Luke began searching for Force lore twenty-nine years before the Starkiller Incident, which Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates to 34 ABY. Therefore, he began traveling the galaxy for Force lore in 5 ABY.

  233. â†‘ 233.00 233.01 233.02 233.03 233.04 233.05 233.06 233.07 233.08 233.09 233.10 233.11 233.12 233.13 The Rise of Kylo Ren 2
  234. â†‘ According to Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary, Luke Skywalker began training his nephew Ben Solo 19 years before the Hosnian Cataclysm. Since Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates the Hosnian Cataclysm to 34 ABY, Solo's Jedi training began in 15 ABY.
  235. â†‘ 235.0 235.1 Star Wars: The Lightsaber Collection
  236. â†‘ Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: A Junior Novel
  237. â†‘ 237.0 237.1 237.2 Ultimate Star Wars, New Edition
  238. â†‘ 238.0 238.1 238.2 238.3 238.4 Legacy of Vader 10
  239. â†‘ Shadow of the Sith takes place seventeen years after the Battle of Endor, which Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates to 4 ABY. Therefore, Shadow of the Sith must take place in 21 ABY.
  240. â†‘ 240.0 240.1 240.2 240.3 Star Wars (2020) 50
  241. â†‘ Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker: The Visual Dictionary states that the Jedi Temple of Luke Skywalker was destroyed six years before the Starkiller Incident, which Star Wars: Galactic Atlas dates to 34 ABY. Therefore, the destruction must have taken place in 28 ABY.
